<script type="text/javascript">
var maindomain_lang = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var main_site_url = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var ajax_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php';	
function getParameterByName(name, url) {
		if(url == null){
		  url = window.location.href;
		}
	    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
	    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
		results = regex.exec(url);
	    if (!results) return null;
	    if (!results[2]) return '';
	    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
	}
	var container_q = getParameterByName('container');
	var d_lang = 'en';	
</script>

<meta property="og:author" content="Tom Fakterman"/>
<meta property="og:authorlink" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/"/>

<meta name="post_tags" content=".NET,AsyncRAT,Formbook,Infostealer,Malicious PowerShell scripts,XWorm"/>
<script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"PhantomVAI Loader Delivers a Range of Infostealers","name":"PhantomVAI Loader Delivers a Range of Infostealers","description":"PhantomVAI is a new loader used to deploy multiple infostealers. We discuss its overall evolution and use of steganography and obfuscated scripts.","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/phantomvai-loader-delivers-infostealers\/","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/phantomvai-loader-delivers-infostealers\/","datePublished":"October 15, 2025","articleBody":"Executive Summary\r\nUnit 42 researchers have been tracking phishing campaigns that use PhantomVAI Loader to deliver information-stealing malware through a multi-stage, evasive infection chain. Threat actors wage these campaigns to deliver obfuscated scripts and loaders that use steganography techniques to conceal payloads.\r\n\r\nThe loader initially used in these campaigns was dubbed Katz Stealer Loader, for the Katz Stealer malware that it delivers. Hackers are selling this new infostealer on underground forums as malware as a service (MaaS). Recently, we observed that the loader now delivers additional infostealers, such as AsyncRAT, XWorm, FormBook and DCRat. Given this unique behavior, we now track the loader under a new name: PhantomVAI Loader. We chose the name because of the loader\u2019s stealth and the VAI method it executes.\r\n\r\nThreat actors deploy PhantomVAI Loader in attacks worldwide, targeting organizations from a wide spectrum of industries:\r\n\r\n \tManufacturing\r\n \tEducation\r\n \tUtilities\r\n \tTechnology\r\n \tHealthcare\r\n \tInformation\r\n \tGovernment\r\n\r\nWe explore each stage of the multi-layered infection chain, from the initial phishing email to the final deployment of the infostealer payload. We also outline the functionality of Katz Stealer specifically.\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers are better protected from this activity through the following products and services:\r\n\r\n \tAdvanced WildFire\r\n \tCortex XDR and XSIAM\r\n\r\nIf you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the Unit 42 Incident Response team.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nRelated Unit 42 Topics\r\nInfostealers\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBackground\r\nOn April 13, 2025, a user called katzadmin posted about a new infostealer named Katz Stealer. The user uploaded these posts to the BreachForums underground forum, and later to the exploit[.]in and xss[.]is forums as well. Katz Stealer is a type of MaaS that collects sensitive data from a variety of applications hosted on infected machines.\r\n\r\nWe observed threat actors delivering Katz Stealer through phishing emails containing obfuscated JavaScript or VBS code, PowerShell scripts and a .NET loader. Initially called Katz Stealer Loader \u2014 and also known as VMDetectLoader \u2014 this loader now delivers infostealers such as AsyncRAT, XWorm, FormBook and DCRat. We track this loader under a new name: PhantomVAI Loader.\r\nInfection Chain Analysis\r\nThe PhantomVAI Loader attack chain starts with an initial phishing operation and culminates in the deployment of payloads. Figure 1 summarizes the steps of this process.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_160760\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"941\"] Figure 1. The PhantomVAI Loader attack chain.[\/caption]\r\nPhishing Emails \r\nThe infection chain starts with a phishing email that contains a malicious attachment. Figure 2 shows an example of one of the phishing emails.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_160771\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 2. Phishing email. Source: VirusTotal.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe emails contain themes like sales, payments and legal actions to trick the targeted users into opening the malicious attachment. Some of these emails incorporate homograph attacks, which involve replacing Latin characters in the email with other Unicode or math characters. Attackers use this technique to bypass email defenses by disguising terms that email security mechanisms usually flag as suspicious.\r\nStage 1: JavaScript and VBS Scripts\r\nThe phishing email attachments are archived JavaScript or VBS files. Threat actors obfuscate these scripts in an attempt to bypass detections. Figure 3 shows an example of obfuscated JavaScript from one of these files.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_160782\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 3. Obfuscated JavaScript.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe script embeds a Base64-encoded PowerShell script and executes it to download and deliver the next stage of the infection.\r\nStage 2: PowerShell Script\r\nThe decoded PowerShell script downloads and loads the next stage of the infection. Figure 4 shows an example of a decoded PowerShell script.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_160793\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 4. PowerShell script used to download the next stages of the attack.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe PowerShell script downloads a GIF or other image file that conceals the loader payload. This technique is known as steganography. In the infections that we observed, threat actors used this technique to embed text within the image. The text is a Base64-encoded DLL file.\r\n\r\nNext, the script extracts the Base64 data by searching for specific strings that represent the start and end of the encoded text. In this case, the PowerShell script searches for all text between &lt;&lt;sudo_png&gt;&gt; and &lt;&lt;sudo_odt&gt;&gt;. This text is an encoded DLL. In other cases, threat actors inserted the encoded text between different headers. Figure 5 shows an example of encoded text embedded in a GIF file using steganography.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_160804\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 5. The start of encoded Base64 text embedded in a GIF file.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nAfter extracting the encoded text from the image or GIF file, the PowerShell script decodes the text and loads the DLL. The loaded DLL is the .NET loader payload that we call PhantomVAI Loader.\r\n\r\nThe PowerShell script invokes a method called VAI within PhantomVAI Loader and provides it with several parameters. The first parameter is a URL for the command and control (C2) server that hosts the final payload.\r\nStage 3: Executing PhantomVAI Loader\r\nPhantomVAI Loader is written in C#, and the VAI method has three main functionalities:\r\n\r\n \tRunning virtual machine checks\r\n \tEstablishing persistence\r\n \tRetrieving the final payload\r\n\r\nVirtual Machine Detection\r\nWhen PhantomVAI Loader is executed, it performs checks to determine whether it is running on a virtual machine, as the code below shows. The VM detection portion of the code appears to be based on a GitHub project named VMDetector. If any of the checks return a true response, PhantomVAI Loader exits and stops executing.\r\nDetected as a virtual machine given key computer information.\r\n\r\nDetected as a virtual machine given bios information.\r\n\r\nDetected as a virtual machine given hard disk information.\r\n\r\nDetected as a virtual machine given PnP devices information.\r\n\r\nDetected as a virtual machine given Windows services information.\r\nEstablishing Persistence\r\nPhantomVAI Loader uses one or all of the following methods to create persistence:\r\n\r\n \tA scheduled task executes PowerShell commands to download a file from an attacker-controlled URL. The task saves the file with a specific name and extension and then executes it.\r\n \tA scheduled task executes a script using wscript.exe. The path to this script is supplied as a command-line parameter.\r\n \tA Run registry key to execute a specific file. The file\u2019s path is also provided as a command-line argument.\r\n\r\nRetrieving Payload and Injection\r\nPhantomVAI Loader downloads the payload from the URL specified as a command-line parameter in the Stage 2 PowerShell script. It then injects this payload into a target process that is also defined by a command-line parameter, using the process hollowing technique. The loader injects the payload into a process located in one of these four paths, depending on the command-line argument and the payload architecture:\r\n\r\n \tC:\\Windows\\Microsoft.NET\\Framework\\v4.0.30319\\\r\n \tC:\\Windows\\Microsoft.NET\\Framework64\\v4.0.30319\\\r\n \tC:\\Windows\\System32\\\r\n \tC:\\Windows\\SysWOW64\\\r\n\r\nIn most of the cases observed at the time of writing this article, PhantomVAI Loader injected the payload into the Microsoft Build Engine executable, MSBuild.exe. Figure 6 shows an example of such an injection, in the context of the infection chain.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_160815\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 6. Infection chain that starts with the user opening an email using msedge.exe (Microsoft Edge browser) and ends with PhantomVAI Loader injecting the payload to MSBuild.exe.[\/caption]\r\nKatz Stealer: A New Malware-as-a-Service Stealer\r\nPhantomVAI Loader has evolved to deliver a number of infostealers. As Katz Stealer is the least well known and documented, we cover it in additional detail here.\r\n\r\nThreat actors use Katz Stealer to steal data from infected machines, such as:\r\n\r\n \tBrowser credentials\r\n \tBrowser data (such as cookies, history, login data)\r\n \tCryptocurrency wallets\r\n \tTelegram data\r\n \tDiscord data\r\n \tOperating system information\r\n \tSteam and game data\r\n \tVPN data\r\n \tFTP clients data\r\n \tCommunication and messaging applications data\r\n \tEmail clients data\r\n \tScreenshots\r\n \tClipboard data\r\n\r\nKatz Stealer also checks the machine\u2019s language and compares it to a hardcoded list of country codes by using the following APIs:\r\n\r\n \tGetKeyboardLayout\r\n \tGetLocaleInfoA\r\n \tGetSystemDefaultLangID\r\n\r\nThe country codes that Katz Stealer checks are all part of the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS), as Figure 7 shows. If it finds a match, Katz Stealer stops executing. This language check and subsequent behavior could provide a clue to the origin of the author of the malware.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_160826\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"700\"] Figure 7. Code snippet showing the country codes that Katz Stealer checks.[\/caption]\r\nConclusion\r\nThis article highlights phishing campaigns that deliver PhantomVAI Loader, also known as Katz Stealer Loader. Combining social engineering via phishing emails, obfuscated scripts, steganography and a .NET loader, this multi-stage infection chain demonstrates the lengths attackers go to in attempts to evade detection and bypass defenses.\r\n\r\nOur research highlights how this loader has evolved in the cybercrime ecosystem. While initially, threat actors used the loader solely to deliver Katz Stealer, recent observations show that the loader now distributes additional malware strains, including AsyncRAT, XWorm, FormBook and DCRat.\r\n\r\nMaaS offerings like Katz Stealer are a pervasive threat that can significantly impact security and privacy by exposing sensitive data such as passwords, networking data, emails and files. Understanding the attack chains and techniques that threat actors use to deliver these malicious payloads is vital to ensuring organization security.\r\nPalo Alto Networks Protection and Mitigation\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed above through the following products and services:\r\n\r\n \tThe Advanced WildFire machine-learning models and analysis techniques have been reviewed and updated in light of the indicators shared in this research.\r\n \tCortex XDR and XSIAM help prevent all the threats described above by employing the Malware Prevention Engine. This approach combines several layers of protection, including Advanced WildFire, Behavioral Threat Protection and the Local Analysis module, to prevent both known and unknown malware from causing harm to endpoints.\r\n\r\nFigure 8 shows two examples of detection alerts that the emails in this campaign trigger in Cortex XDR.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_160837\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 8. Detection of phishing emails that contain suspicious themes and homograph characters.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nIf you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the Unit 42 Incident Response team or call:\r\n\r\n \tNorth America: Toll Free: +1 (866) 486-4842 (866.4.UNIT42)\r\n \tUK: +44.20.3743.3660\r\n \tEurope and Middle East: +31.20.299.3130\r\n \tAsia: +65.6983.8730\r\n \tJapan: +81.50.1790.0200\r\n \tAustralia: +61.2.4062.7950\r\n \tIndia: 00080005045107\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the Cyber Threat Alliance.\r\nIndicators of Compromise\r\n\r\nSHA256 Hash for Archive Example\r\n\r\n \t02aa167e4bb41e3e40a75954f5a0bd5915f9a16fd6c21b544a557f2a7df3c89b\r\n\r\nSHA256 Hashes for JavaScript Examples\r\n\r\n \te663916cc91b4285a1ee762716ff7ce4537153c7893e2d88c13c7e57bbb646a9\r\n \t45fddf55acb50df5b027701073dee604b4135f750c585b29d6dcac824f26ae00\r\n \t9f28f82d21fe99d0efdcab403f73870d68fd94e6d0f762e658d923ccd1e7424c\r\n \t05d66568017f2c2e417fa6680f9b4fa4a8a9bc1b7256fe46fbf3e71956b99773\r\n \t4346c3c08df612b8bcd23a3b57845755bafb0efc57ff77203f8da3b46628a008\r\n \t0c0dae4d7da069c928f06addb1c5c824e820e4556a1244142f56227954bf9c7d\r\n \t3a039ce210a0b5ff65f57d304519b885bae91d1bec345c54e59e07bc39fca97e\r\n\r\nSHA256 Hashes for PhantomVAI Loader\r\n\r\n \t4ab4a37db01eba53ee47b31cba60c7a3771b759633717e2c7b9c75310f57f429\r\n \t4c5d7e437f59b41f9f321be8c17ae1f128c04628107a36f83df21b33d12ff8db\r\n \t639eb0d2c2da5487412e7891638b334927232ff270781fad81dc5371f44f7c8e\r\n \ta62a81785714844a099a918c66df9367b5eb14df06e589d59bc81f392358c5cc\r\n \t920309f3822f993afeaa8ec70b4ef6b43dd2562be85cc2985efedc6cda2e7578\r\n \t421c4b4b53d291da2b53c068a491b3913d92fe0eb6f330861e7b60f3d9f8eee7\r\n \t87fae395c0e9ce3631dece94971befa578623ff0540d06539f583df921568814\r\n \t4b8bde867c06b617d731ea9e965bf64800330701942324e475b8119352122e7c\r\n \t3c6a8132df3351e2b7d186d0b3f41847e6920ebcb940548e3c9ed274901104c2\r\n \t76cbb0abd9511aab2cc9dda993e3b9ab77afb09d2959f143647065ca47e725cc\r\n \ted1b4a03595c59e5a90dd4f02f1993a2c5a43ca46a33aab0d15a1bbb1f8b3d30\r\n \tc44bac8b66ad11756b4c5ff3b1cd7e1187c634088f9e7aa2250067033df24e8d\r\n \t63dfdb4927c0bca64f8952904f463330360eb052f2a2a749bf91a851a2be89b4\r\n \t373c820cc395ea5b9c6f38b9470913e6684e8afea59e9dfeb3da490014074bf1\r\n \tb263df6b58c9259000e45a238327de8c07e79f2e7462c2b687c1c5771bac1dd5\r\n \tf05bc36211301087e403df09daa014ea8f04f5bdae5cef75eb866b56b82af2d6\r\n \tc45d3b6d2237fc500688a73d3ba18335d0002917f1a1f09df6934c87deaa097f\r\n \tfcad234dc2ad5e2d8215bcf6caac29aef62666c34564e723fa6d2eee8b6468ed\r\n \te05b7f44ef8d0b58cfc2f407b84dcff1cb24e0ec392f792a49ad71e7eab39143\r\n \t87c9bede1feac2e3810f3d269b4492fe0902e6303020171e561face400e9bdb4\r\n \tc3de728850dc1e777ad50a211a4be212ca6c4ac9d94bf7bb6d5f7fe5f4574021\r\n \te5daa86418ac444d590a2c693cd7749d87134c47d8e0dbac30c69f23a8e8131f\r\n\r\n\r\nSHA256 Hashes for Katz Stealer\r\n\r\n \ta6b736988246610da83ce17c2c15af189d3a3a4f82233e4fedfabdcbbde0cff0\r\n \t74052cf53b45399b31743a6c4d3a1643e125a277e4ddcfcad4f2903b32bc7dc4\r\n \t20bde6276d6355d33396d5ebfc523b4f4587f706b599573de78246811aabd33c\r\n \te345d793477abbecc2c455c8c76a925c0dfe99ec4c65b7c353e8a8c8b14da2b6\r\n \t96ada593d54949707437fa39628960b1c5d142a5b1cb371339acc8f86dbc7678\r\n \t925e6375deaa38d978e00a73f9353a9d0df81f023ab85cf9a1dc046e403830a8\r\n \tb249814a74dff9316dc29b670e1d8ed80eb941b507e206ca0dfdc4ff033b1c1f\r\n <script>var $ = jQuery;</script>

    <script type="text/javascript">
    ;(function(win, doc, style, timeout) {
    var STYLE_ID = 'at-body-style';
    function getParent() {
    return doc.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
    }
    function addStyle(parent, id, def) {
        if (!parent) {
        return;
        }
        var style = doc.createElement('style');
        style.id = id;
        style.innerHTML = def;
        parent.appendChild(style);
    }
    function removeStyle(parent, id) {
        if (!parent) {
            return;
        }
        var style = doc.getElementById(id);
        if (!style) {
            return;
        }
        parent.removeChild(style);
    }
    addStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID, style);
    setTimeout(function() {
    removeStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID);
    }, timeout);
    }(window, document, "body {visibility:hidden !important}", 3000));
    </script>

            <script src="https://assets.adobedtm.com/9273d4aedcd2/0d76ae0322d7/launch-425c423d843b.min.js" async></script>
            <script type="text/javascript" src="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/content/dam/pan/en_US/includes/attribution.js"></script>


<script type="text/javascript">
var isIE11 = !!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./);
if(isIE11){
    var polyfill = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/scripts/polyfill.min.js';
    document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src="'+polyfill+'">\x3C/script>');
}
    /**
 * String.prototype.replaceAll() polyfill
 * https://gomakethings.com/how-to-replace-a-section-of-a-string-with-another-one-with-vanilla-js/
 * @author Chris Ferdinandi
 * @license MIT
 */
if (!String.prototype.replaceAll) {
	String.prototype.replaceAll = function(str, newStr){
		// If a regex pattern
		if (Object.prototype.toString.call(str).toLowerCase() === '[object regexp]') {
			return this.replace(str, newStr);
		}
		// If a string
		return this.replace(new RegExp(str, 'g'), newStr);
	};
}

    /*! lozad.js - v1.16.0 - 2020-09-06 */
!function(t,e){"object"==typeof exports&&"undefined"!=typeof module?module.exports=e():"function"==typeof define&&define.amd?define(e):t.lozad=e()}(this,function(){"use strict";
/**
   * Detect IE browser
   * @const {boolean}
   * @private
   */var g="undefined"!=typeof document&&document.documentMode,f={rootMargin:"0px",threshold:0,load:function(t){if("picture"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()){var e=t.querySelector("img"),r=!1;null===e&&(e=document.createElement("img"),r=!0),g&&t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")&&(e.src=t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")),t.getAttribute("data-alt")&&(e.alt=t.getAttribute("data-alt")),r&&t.append(e)}if("video"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()&&!t.getAttribute("data-src")&&t.children){for(var a=t.children,o=void 0,i=0;i<=a.length-1;i++)(o=a[i].getAttribute("data-src"))&&(a[i].src=o);t.load()}t.getAttribute("data-poster")&&(t.poster=t.getAttribute("data-poster")),t.getAttribute("data-src")&&(t.src=t.getAttribute("data-src")),t.getAttribute("data-srcset")&&t.setAttribute("srcset",t.getAttribute("data-srcset"));var n=",";if(t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")&&(n=t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")),t.getAttribute("data-background-image"))t.style.backgroundImage="url('"+t.getAttribute("data-background-image").split(n).join("'),url('")+"')";else if(t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set")){var d=t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set").split(n),u=d[0].substr(0,d[0].indexOf(" "))||d[0];// Substring before ... 1x
u=-1===u.indexOf("url(")?"url("+u+")":u,1===d.length?t.style.backgroundImage=u:t.setAttribute("style",(t.getAttribute("style")||"")+"background-image: "+u+"; background-image: -webkit-image-set("+d+"); background-image: image-set("+d+")")}t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class")&&t.classList.toggle(t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class"))},loaded:function(){}};function A(t){t.setAttribute("data-loaded",!0)}var m=function(t){return"true"===t.getAttribute("data-loaded")},v=function(t){var e=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:document;return t instanceof Element?[t]:t instanceof NodeList?t:e.querySelectorAll(t)};return function(){var r,a,o=0<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[0]?arguments[0]:".lozad",t=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:{},e=Object.assign({},f,t),i=e.root,n=e.rootMargin,d=e.threshold,u=e.load,g=e.loaded,s=void 0;"undefined"!=typeof window&&window.IntersectionObserver&&(s=new IntersectionObserver((r=u,a=g,function(t,e){t.forEach(function(t){(0<t.intersectionRatio||t.isIntersecting)&&(e.unobserve(t.target),m(t.target)||(r(t.target),A(t.target),a(t.target)))})}),{root:i,rootMargin:n,threshold:d}));for(var c,l=v(o,i),b=0;b<l.length;b++)(c=l[b]).getAttribute("data-placeholder-background")&&(c.style.background=c.getAttribute("data-placeholder-background"));return{observe:function(){for(var t=v(o,i),e=0;e<t.length;e++)m(t[e])||(s?s.observe(t[e]):(u(t[e]),A(t[e]),g(t[e])))},triggerLoad:function(t){m(t)||(u(t),A(t),g(t))},observer:s}}});

</script>

    </head>

    <ul id="menu-primary-navigation" class="main-menu d-sm-flex font-weight-medium"><li id="menu-item-97290" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-97290"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tools/">Tools</a></li>

<div class="panClean pan-template-home" id="main-nav-menu-cont" style="display:none;">
    <div class="cleanHeader mainNavigationComp baseComponent parbase">
        <div class="productNav2021Component dark default" id="PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC">

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
	function getCookie(cname) {
	 	var name = cname + "=";
  		var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
		var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  		for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    			var c = ca[i];
    			while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
     				 c = c.substring(1);
    			}
    			if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
    				 return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    			}
  		}
  		return "";
	}

	var referer = "";//sessionStorage.container;
	var pcontainer = sessionStorage.getItem("container");
	var searchResultsPagePath = "";
	if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Prisma')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Prisma' ;
	}        
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Cortex')!=-1)){
            if( pcontainer.indexOf('CloudCortex') != -1){
                referer = 'CloudCortex' ;
            }
            else{
                referer = 'Cortex' ;
            }	    
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Sase')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Sase' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Unit')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Unit' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Ngfw')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Ngfw' ;
	}
        var fromRef = document.referrer;
        var nContainer = getCookie("navContainer");
        if(nContainer){//If user is coming from main site, we need to reset the container		
		if(fromRef  && fromRef.indexOf("prismacloud.io")!=-1){
                        referer = 'Prisma' ;
                        sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                } else if(fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.com")!=-1 || fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.jp")!=-1 ){
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Prisma') != -1){
                            referer = 'Prisma' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                        }
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Cortex') != -1){
                            if( nContainer.indexOf('CloudCortex') != -1){
                                referer = 'CloudCortex';
                                sessionStorage.setItem("container","CloudCortex");
                            }
                            else{
                                referer = 'Cortex';
                                sessionStorage.setItem("container","Cortex");
                            }                            
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Sase') != -1){
                            referer = 'Sase' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Sase");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Unit') != -1){
                            referer = 'Unit' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Ngfw') != -1){
                            referer = 'Ngfw' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Ngfw");
                        }
			document.cookie = 'navContainer=; path=/; domain=.paloaltonetworks.com; expires=' + new Date(0).toUTCString();
		}
	}
if(referer != "Prisma" && referer != "CloudCortex" && referer != "Cortex" && referer != "Sase" && referer != "Unit" && referer != "Ngfw") {
    referer = 'Unit' ;
    sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
}
function callMainSitePrismaNavHTML(){
    
    var referrer_domain = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
    sessionStorage.setItem("domain",referrer_domain);
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        //var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html';
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=prisma&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/prismasearch";
        }
    if(referer == 'CloudCortex'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=cortexcloud&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexcloudsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        //var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderCortex.cortexRenderer.html';	
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=cortex&domain=en';	
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Sase'){
        //var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderSase.saseRenderer.html';
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=sase&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/sasesearch";
    }
    if(referer == 'Unit'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=unit42&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/content/pan/en_US/search/unit42search";
		    }
    if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        //var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/ngfw-cdss-nav-renderer.php';
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=ngfw&domain=en'; 
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/ngfwcdsssearch";
    }
    httpGet(menu_url,'menu_html');
    document.getElementById('main-nav-menu-cont').removeAttribute("style");
}
function addStyle(styles) {            
    /* Create style document */
    var css = document.createElement('style');
    css.type = 'text/css';

    if (css.styleSheet) 
        css.styleSheet.cssText = styles;
    else 
        css.appendChild(document.createTextNode(styles));

    /* Append style to the tag name */
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(css);
}
function httpGet(theUrl,req_type) {
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest) { // code for IE7+, Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Safari
        xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else {// code for IE6, IE5
        xmlhttp=new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }
    xmlhttp.onreadystatechange=function()
    {
        if (xmlhttp.readyState==4 && xmlhttp.status==200)
        {
            if(req_type == 'menu_html'){
            var nav_text = xmlhttp.responseText.replaceAll('https://static.cloud.coveo.com/searchui/v2.9159/js/CoveoJsSearch.Lazy.min.js', '');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll('src="/', 'src="'+maindomain_lang+'/');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll("'/content", "'"+maindomain_lang+"/content");
                        
            document.getElementById("PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC").innerHTML = nav_text.replaceAll('href="/', 'href="'+maindomain_lang+'/');

            var lozad_back = document.getElementsByClassName('lozad-background');
            Array.prototype.forEach.call(lozad_back, function(el) {
            // Do stuff here
            var el_back_img_path = el.getAttribute('data-background-image');
            var first_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'");
            var last_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'",first_pos+1);
            el_back_img_path = el_back_img_path.substring(first_pos+1,last_pos);
            el.setAttribute("data-background-image",main_site_url+el_back_img_path);
            });
            const observer_lozad = lozad('.lozad, .lozad-background'); // lazy loads elements with default selector as '.lozad'
            observer_lozad.observe();
            }
            if(req_type == 'head_inline_css'){
            addStyle(xmlhttp.responseText);
            }
        }
    }
    xmlhttp.open("GET", theUrl, true );
    xmlhttp.send();    
}    
    
if(referer == 'Prisma' || referer == 'CloudCortex' || referer == 'Cortex' || referer == 'Sase' || referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
    const article = document.querySelector('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC');
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        article.dataset.type = 'prisma';
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    else if(referer == 'CloudCortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cloudcortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Sase'){
        article.dataset.type = 'sase';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Unit'){
        article.dataset.type = 'unit';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        article.dataset.type = 'ngfw';
    }
    //set class to default
    if(referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    callMainSitePrismaNavHTML();
}
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

          <div class="ab__footer">
            <div class="l-container">
              <div class="ab__footer-wrapper">
                <ul class="ab__features" role="list">
                  <li role="listitem">
				 <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-profile-grey.svg" alt="Profile Icon">
					 <div class="ab__text"><span>By:</span><ul class="ab__tags"><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="phantomvai-loader-delivers-infostealers:hero:Tom Fakterman" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/tom-fakterman/">Tom Fakterman</a></li></ul></div></li>                  <li role="listitem">
			<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-calendar-grey.svg" alt="Published Icon">
			<div class="ab__text"><span>Published:</span>October 15, 2025</div></li>					<li role="listitem"><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-category.svg" alt="Tags Icon"><div class="ab__text"><span>Categories:</span><ul class="ab__tags"><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="phantomvai-loader-delivers-infostealers:hero:Malware" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/malware/">Malware</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="phantomvai-loader-delivers-infostealers:hero:Threat Research" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/">Threat Research</a></li></ul></div>
		</li>                  <li role="listitem"><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-tags-grey.svg" alt="Tags Icon"><div class="ab__text"><span>Tags:</span><ul class="ab__tags"><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="phantomvai-loader-delivers-infostealers:hero:.NET" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/net/">.NET</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="phantomvai-loader-delivers-infostealers:hero:AsyncRAT" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/asyncrat/">AsyncRAT</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="phantomvai-loader-delivers-infostealers:hero:Formbook" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/formbook/">Formbook</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="phantomvai-loader-delivers-infostealers:hero:Infostealer" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/infostealer/">Infostealer</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="phantomvai-loader-delivers-infostealers:hero:Malicious PowerShell scripts" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/malicious-powershell-scripts/">Malicious PowerShell scripts</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="phantomvai-loader-delivers-infostealers:hero:XWorm" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/xworm/">XWorm</a></li></ul></div>
		</li>                </ul>
                <div class="ab__options">
                  <ul role="list">
                                        <li role="listitem"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/phantomvai-loader-delivers-infostealers/?pdf=download&#038;lg=en&#038;_wpnonce=e84f3c0177" role="link" target="_blank"  title="Click here to download" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="phantomvai-loader-delivers-infostealers:hero:pdfdownload"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-download.svg" alt="Download Icon"></a></li>
                    <li role="listitem"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/phantomvai-loader-delivers-infostealers/?pdf=print&#038;lg=en&#038;_wpnonce=e84f3c0177" target="_blank" role="link" title="Click here to print" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="phantomvai-loader-delivers-infostealers:hero:pdfprint"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-print.svg" alt="Print Icon"></a></li>
                  </ul>
                  
	<div class="ab__share" id="shareDropdown" role="button" aria-expanded="false">

              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <h2><a id="post-160748-_4lt92rr5muov"></a>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>Unit 42 researchers have been tracking phishing campaigns that use PhantomVAI Loader to deliver information-stealing malware through a multi-stage, evasive infection chain. Threat actors wage these campaigns to deliver obfuscated scripts and loaders that use <a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/003/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">steganography</a> techniques to conceal payloads.</p>
<p>The loader initially used in these campaigns was dubbed Katz Stealer Loader, for the Katz Stealer malware that it delivers. Hackers are selling this new infostealer on underground forums as malware as a service (MaaS). Recently, we observed that the loader now delivers additional infostealers, such as <a href="https://malpedia.caad.fkie.fraunhofer.de/details/win.asyncrat" target="_blank" rel="noopener">AsyncRAT</a>, <a href="https://malpedia.caad.fkie.fraunhofer.de/details/win.xworm" target="_blank" rel="noopener">XWorm</a>, <a href="https://malpedia.caad.fkie.fraunhofer.de/details/win.formbook" target="_blank" rel="noopener">FormBook</a> and <a href="https://malpedia.caad.fkie.fraunhofer.de/details/win.dcrat" target="_blank" rel="noopener">DCRat</a>. Given this unique behavior, we now track the loader under a new name: PhantomVAI Loader. We chose the name because of the loader’s stealth and the VAI method it executes.</p>
<p>Threat actors deploy PhantomVAI Loader in attacks worldwide, targeting organizations from a wide spectrum of industries:</p>
<ul>
<li>Manufacturing</li>
<li>Education</li>
<li>Utilities</li>
<li>Technology</li>
<li>Healthcare</li>
<li>Information</li>
<li>Government</li>
</ul>
<p>We explore each stage of the multi-layered infection chain, from the initial phishing email to the final deployment of the infostealer payload. We also outline the functionality of Katz Stealer specifically.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from this activity through the following products and services:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a></li>
<li><a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XDR" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR</a> and <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XSIAM" target="_blank" rel="noopener">XSIAM</a></li>
</ul>
<p>If you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a>.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 35%;"><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td style="width: 100%;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/infostealer/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><b>Infostealers</b></a></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-160748-_8hzufrtevdg2"></a>Background</h2>
<p>On April 13, 2025, a user called <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">katzadmin</span> posted about a new infostealer named Katz Stealer. The user uploaded these posts to the BreachForums underground forum, and later to the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">exploit[.]in</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">xss[.]is</span> forums as well. Katz Stealer is a type of MaaS that collects sensitive data from a variety of applications hosted on infected machines.</p>
<p>We observed threat actors delivering Katz Stealer through phishing emails containing obfuscated JavaScript or VBS code, PowerShell scripts and a .NET loader. Initially called Katz Stealer Loader — and also known as <a href="https://www.ibm.com/think/x-force/dcrat-presence-growing-in-latin-america" target="_blank" rel="noopener">VMDetectLoader</a> — this loader now delivers infostealers such as <a href="https://malpedia.caad.fkie.fraunhofer.de/details/win.asyncrat" target="_blank" rel="noopener">AsyncRAT</a>, <a href="https://malpedia.caad.fkie.fraunhofer.de/details/win.xworm" target="_blank" rel="noopener">XWorm</a>, <a href="https://malpedia.caad.fkie.fraunhofer.de/details/win.formbook" target="_blank" rel="noopener">FormBook</a> and <a href="https://malpedia.caad.fkie.fraunhofer.de/details/win.dcrat" target="_blank" rel="noopener">DCRat</a>. We track this loader under a new name: PhantomVAI Loader.</p>
<h2><a id="post-160748-_wven14kmgum2"></a>Infection Chain Analysis</h2>
<p>The PhantomVAI Loader attack chain starts with an initial phishing operation and culminates in the deployment of payloads. Figure 1 summarizes the steps of this process.</p>
<figure id="attachment_160760" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-160760" style="width: 941px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-160760 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-188912-160748-1.png" alt="Flowchart detailing a cyberattack involving a phishing email, leading to the download of various files including archives and scripts, utilizing tools like PowerShell, and culminating in the injection of an infostealer via PhantomVAI loader. " width="941" height="570" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-188912-160748-1.png 941w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-188912-160748-1-726x440.png 726w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-188912-160748-1-768x465.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 941px) 100vw, 941px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-160760" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. The PhantomVAI Loader attack chain.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-160748-_puej9mifz0nb"></a><strong>Phishing Emails </strong></h3>
<p>The infection chain starts with a phishing email that contains a malicious attachment. Figure 2 shows an example of one of the phishing emails.</p>
<figure id="attachment_160771" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-160771" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-160771 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-191968-160748-2.png" alt="Email screenshot displaying a message about a new shipment order, including a document attachment. The sender is identified as a cargo logistics company, referencing confirmation of shipment documents. The text in the email includes contact details and a website URL" width="1000" height="921" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-191968-160748-2.png 1712w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-191968-160748-2-478x440.png 478w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-191968-160748-2-760x700.png 760w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-191968-160748-2-768x707.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-191968-160748-2-1536x1414.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-160771" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. Phishing email. Source: <a href="https://www.virustotal.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">VirusTotal</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The emails contain themes like sales, payments and legal actions to trick the targeted users into opening the malicious attachment. Some of these emails incorporate <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/homograph-attacks/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">homograph attacks</a>, which involve replacing Latin characters in the email with other Unicode or math characters. Attackers use this technique to bypass email defenses by disguising terms that email security mechanisms usually flag as suspicious.</p>
<h3><a id="post-160748-_tt2ro3wqe8tu"></a>Stage 1: JavaScript and VBS Scripts</h3>
<p>The phishing email attachments are archived JavaScript or VBS files. Threat actors obfuscate these scripts in an attempt to bypass detections. Figure 3 shows an example of obfuscated JavaScript from one of these files.</p>
<figure id="attachment_160782" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-160782" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-160782 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-195981-160748-3.png" alt="Screenshot of obfuscated JavaScript in a text editor, displaying multiple lines with syntax highlighting." width="1000" height="173" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-195981-160748-3.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-195981-160748-3-786x136.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-195981-160748-3-1920x333.png 1920w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-195981-160748-3-768x133.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-195981-160748-3-1536x266.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-160782" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. Obfuscated JavaScript.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The script embeds a Base64-encoded PowerShell script and executes it to download and deliver the next stage of the infection.</p>
<h3><a id="post-160748-_mxoteg9ghv6e"></a>Stage 2: PowerShell Script</h3>
<p>The decoded PowerShell script downloads and loads the next stage of the infection. Figure 4 shows an example of a decoded PowerShell script.</p>
<figure id="attachment_160793" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-160793" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-160793 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-199360-160748-4.png" alt="Screenshot of the PowerShell script containing the steganography, highlighted by a box and arrow. The last line is the PhantomVAI loader command-line arguments." width="1000" height="197" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-199360-160748-4.png 1652w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-199360-160748-4-786x155.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-199360-160748-4-768x151.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-199360-160748-4-1536x302.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-160793" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. PowerShell script used to download the next stages of the attack.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The PowerShell script downloads a GIF or other image file that conceals the loader payload. This technique is known as <a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/003/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">steganography</a>. In the infections that we observed, threat actors used this technique to embed text within the image. The text is a Base64-encoded DLL file.</p>
<p>Next, the script extracts the Base64 data by searching for specific strings that represent the start and end of the encoded text. In this case, the PowerShell script searches for all text between <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">&lt;&lt;sudo_png&gt;&gt;</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">&lt;&lt;sudo_odt&gt;&gt;</span>. This text is an encoded DLL. In other cases, threat actors inserted the encoded text between different headers. Figure 5 shows an example of encoded text embedded in a GIF file using steganography.</p>
<figure id="attachment_160804" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-160804" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-160804 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-202308-160748-5.png" alt="Screenshot of computer code in an editor, featuring various lines of text in white and gray on a black background. The text includes various programming syntax and keywords with a section highlighted in red that says 'sudo png'." width="1000" height="303" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-202308-160748-5.png 1500w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-202308-160748-5-786x238.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-202308-160748-5-768x232.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-160804" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. The start of encoded Base64 text embedded in a GIF file.</figcaption></figure>
<p>After extracting the encoded text from the image or GIF file, the PowerShell script decodes the text and loads the DLL. The loaded DLL is the .NET loader payload that we call PhantomVAI Loader.</p>
<p>The PowerShell script invokes a method called <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">VAI</span> within PhantomVAI Loader and provides it with several parameters. The first parameter is a URL for the command and control (C2) server that hosts the final payload.</p>
<h3><a id="post-160748-_dwvd86hy08wu"></a>Stage 3: Executing PhantomVAI Loader</h3>
<p>PhantomVAI Loader is written in C#, and the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">VAI</span> method has three main functionalities:</p>
<ul>
<li>Running virtual machine checks</li>
<li>Establishing persistence</li>
<li>Retrieving the final payload</li>
</ul>
<h4><a id="post-160748-_tp3nwrkra3ic"></a>Virtual Machine Detection</h4>
<p>When PhantomVAI Loader is executed, it performs checks to determine whether it is running on a virtual machine, as the code below shows. The VM detection portion of the code appears to be based on a GitHub project named <a href="https://github.com/robsonfelix/VMDetector" target="_blank" rel="noopener">VMDetector</a>. If any of the checks return a true response, PhantomVAI Loader exits and stops executing.</p><!-- Crayon Syntax Highlighter v_2.7.2_beta -->

		<div id="crayon-68f0368e3fdbb296599388" class="crayon-syntax crayon-theme-classic crayon-font-monaco crayon-os-pc print-yes notranslate" data-settings=" minimize scroll-mouseover wrap" style=" margin-top: 12px; margin-bottom: 12px; font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important;">
		
			<div class="crayon-toolbar" data-settings=" mouseover overlay hide delay" style="font-size: 12px !important;height: 18px !important; line-height: 18px !important;"><span class="crayon-title"></span>
			<div class="crayon-tools" style="font-size: 12px !important;height: 18px !important; line-height: 18px !important;"><div class="crayon-button crayon-nums-button" title="Toggle Line Numbers"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-plain-button" title="Toggle Plain Code"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-wrap-button" title="Toggle Line Wrap"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-expand-button" title="Expand Code"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-copy-button" title="Copy"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div><div class="crayon-button crayon-popup-button" title="Open Code In New Window"><div class="crayon-button-icon"></div></div></div></div>
			<div class="crayon-info" style="min-height: 16.8px !important; line-height: 16.8px !important;"></div>
			<div class="crayon-plain-wrap"><textarea  class="crayon-plain print-no" data-settings="dblclick" readonly style="-moz-tab-size:4; -o-tab-size:4; -webkit-tab-size:4; tab-size:4; font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important;">
Detected as a virtual machine given key computer information.

Detected as a virtual machine given bios information.

Detected as a virtual machine given hard disk information.

Detected as a virtual machine given PnP devices information.

Detected as a virtual machine given Windows services information.</textarea></div>
			<div class="crayon-main" style="">
				<table class="crayon-table">
					<tr class="crayon-row">
				<td class="crayon-nums " data-settings="show">
					<div class="crayon-nums-content" style="font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important;"><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68f0368e3fdbb296599388-1">1</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68f0368e3fdbb296599388-2">2</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68f0368e3fdbb296599388-3">3</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68f0368e3fdbb296599388-4">4</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68f0368e3fdbb296599388-5">5</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68f0368e3fdbb296599388-6">6</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68f0368e3fdbb296599388-7">7</div><div class="crayon-num crayon-striped-num" data-line="crayon-68f0368e3fdbb296599388-8">8</div><div class="crayon-num" data-line="crayon-68f0368e3fdbb296599388-9">9</div></div>
				</td>
						<td class="crayon-code"><div class="crayon-pre" style="font-size: 12px !important; line-height: 15px !important; -moz-tab-size:4; -o-tab-size:4; -webkit-tab-size:4; tab-size:4;"><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68f0368e3fdbb296599388-1"><span class="crayon-e">Detected </span><span class="crayon-st">as</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">a</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-e">virtual </span><span class="crayon-e">machine </span><span class="crayon-e">given </span><span class="crayon-e">key </span><span class="crayon-e">computer </span><span class="crayon-i">information</span><span class="crayon-sy">.</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68f0368e3fdbb296599388-2">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68f0368e3fdbb296599388-3"><span class="crayon-e">Detected </span><span class="crayon-st">as</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">a</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-e">virtual </span><span class="crayon-e">machine </span><span class="crayon-e">given </span><span class="crayon-e">bios </span><span class="crayon-i">information</span><span class="crayon-sy">.</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68f0368e3fdbb296599388-4">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68f0368e3fdbb296599388-5"><span class="crayon-e">Detected </span><span class="crayon-st">as</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">a</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-e">virtual </span><span class="crayon-e">machine </span><span class="crayon-e">given </span><span class="crayon-e">hard </span><span class="crayon-e">disk </span><span class="crayon-i">information</span><span class="crayon-sy">.</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68f0368e3fdbb296599388-6">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68f0368e3fdbb296599388-7"><span class="crayon-e">Detected </span><span class="crayon-st">as</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">a</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-e">virtual </span><span class="crayon-e">machine </span><span class="crayon-e">given </span><span class="crayon-e">PnP </span><span class="crayon-e">devices </span><span class="crayon-i">information</span><span class="crayon-sy">.</span></div><div class="crayon-line crayon-striped-line" id="crayon-68f0368e3fdbb296599388-8">&nbsp;</div><div class="crayon-line" id="crayon-68f0368e3fdbb296599388-9"><span class="crayon-e">Detected </span><span class="crayon-st">as</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-i">a</span><span class="crayon-h"> </span><span class="crayon-e">virtual </span><span class="crayon-e">machine </span><span class="crayon-e">given </span><span class="crayon-e">Windows </span><span class="crayon-e">services </span><span class="crayon-i">information</span><span class="crayon-sy">.</span></div></div></td>
					</tr>
				</table>
			</div>
		</div>
<!-- [Format Time: 0.0002 seconds] -->
<p></p>
<h4><a id="post-160748-_bpt870que0mh"></a>Establishing Persistence</h4>
<p>PhantomVAI Loader uses one or all of the following methods to create persistence:</p>
<ul>
<li>A scheduled task executes PowerShell commands to download a file from an attacker-controlled URL. The task saves the file with a specific name and extension and then executes it.</li>
<li>A scheduled task executes a script using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">wscript.exe</span>. The path to this script is supplied as a command-line parameter.</li>
<li>A <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Run</span> registry key to execute a specific file. The file’s path is also provided as a command-line argument.</li>
</ul>
<h4><a id="post-160748-_37sogngirbip"></a>Retrieving Payload and Injection</h4>
<p>PhantomVAI Loader downloads the payload from the URL specified as a command-line parameter in the Stage 2 PowerShell script. It then injects this payload into a target process that is also defined by a command-line parameter, using the <a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1055/012/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">process hollowing</a> technique. The loader injects the payload into a process located in one of these four paths, depending on the command-line argument and the payload architecture:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\Framework\v4.0.30319\</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\Framework64\v4.0.30319\</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C:\Windows\System32\</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C:\Windows\SysWOW64\</span></li>
</ul>
<p>In most of the cases observed at the time of writing this article, PhantomVAI Loader injected the payload into the <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/msbuild/msbuild?view=vs-2022" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Microsoft Build Engine</a> executable, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MSBuild.exe</span>. Figure 6 shows an example of such an injection, in the context of the infection chain.</p>
<figure id="attachment_160815" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-160815" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-160815 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-206096-160748-6.png" alt="Screenshot of the Cortex XDR interface showing four files: msedge.exe, wscript.exe, powershell.exe, and MSBuild.exe. Each file has a corresponding icon, with powershell.exe displaying a warning symbol and associated error code. It is marked at the loaded PhantomVAI loader. " width="1000" height="361" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-206096-160748-6.png 1650w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-206096-160748-6-786x283.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-206096-160748-6-768x277.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-206096-160748-6-1536x554.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-160815" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. Infection chain that starts with the user opening an email using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">msedge.exe</span> (Microsoft Edge browser) and ends with PhantomVAI Loader injecting the payload to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">MSBuild.exe</span>.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-160748-_e9pipkvdbnvi"></a>Katz Stealer: A New Malware-as-a-Service Stealer</h2>
<p>PhantomVAI Loader has evolved to deliver a number of infostealers. As Katz Stealer is the least well known and documented, we cover it in additional detail here.</p>
<p>Threat actors use Katz Stealer to steal data from infected machines, such as:</p>
<ul>
<li>Browser credentials</li>
<li>Browser data (such as cookies, history, login data)</li>
<li>Cryptocurrency wallets</li>
<li>Telegram data</li>
<li>Discord data</li>
<li>Operating system information</li>
<li>Steam and game data</li>
<li>VPN data</li>
<li>FTP clients data</li>
<li>Communication and messaging applications data</li>
<li>Email clients data</li>
<li>Screenshots</li>
<li>Clipboard data</li>
</ul>
<p>Katz Stealer also checks the machine’s language and compares it to a hardcoded list of country codes by using the following APIs:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GetKeyboardLayout</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GetLocaleInfoA</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">GetSystemDefaultLangID</span></li>
</ul>
<p>The country codes that Katz Stealer checks are all part of the <a href="https://www.britannica.com/topic/Commonwealth-of-Independent-States" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS)</a>, as Figure 7 shows. If it finds a match, Katz Stealer stops executing. This language check and subsequent behavior could provide a clue to the origin of the author of the malware.</p>
<figure id="attachment_160826" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-160826" style="width: 700px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-160826 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-209363-160748-7.png" alt="Screenshot of code with country codes and their corresponding full names, including Russia, Belarus, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, Armenia, Azerbaijan, and Moldova. Each entry is prefixed with &quot;dq offset.&quot; " width="700" height="182" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-209363-160748-7.png 1092w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-209363-160748-7-786x204.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-209363-160748-7-768x200.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-160826" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. Code snippet showing the country codes that Katz Stealer checks.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-160748-_2an8ryq91inv"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>This article highlights phishing campaigns that deliver PhantomVAI Loader, also known as Katz Stealer Loader. Combining social engineering via phishing emails, obfuscated scripts, steganography and a .NET loader, this multi-stage infection chain demonstrates the lengths attackers go to in attempts to evade detection and bypass defenses.</p>
<p>Our research highlights how this loader has evolved in the cybercrime ecosystem. While initially, threat actors used the loader solely to deliver Katz Stealer, recent observations show that the loader now distributes additional malware strains, including AsyncRAT, XWorm, FormBook and DCRat.</p>
<p>MaaS offerings like Katz Stealer are a pervasive threat that can significantly impact security and privacy by exposing sensitive data such as passwords, networking data, emails and files. Understanding the attack chains and techniques that threat actors use to deliver these malicious payloads is vital to ensuring organization security.</p>
<h3><a id="post-160748-_lsbythhc3nz9"></a>Palo Alto Networks Protection and Mitigation</h3>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed above through the following products and services:</p>
<ul>
<li>The <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a> machine-learning models and analysis techniques have been reviewed and updated in light of the indicators shared in this research.</li>
<li><a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XDR" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR</a> and <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XSIAM" target="_blank" rel="noopener">XSIAM</a> help prevent all the threats described above by employing the <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/r/Cortex-XDR/Cortex-XDR-4.x-Documentation/Malware-protection" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Malware Prevention Engine</a>. This approach combines several layers of protection, including <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a>, Behavioral Threat Protection and the Local Analysis module, to prevent both known and unknown malware from causing harm to endpoints.</li>
</ul>
<p>Figure 8 shows two examples of detection alerts that the emails in this campaign trigger in Cortex XDR.</p>
<figure id="attachment_160837" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-160837" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-160837 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-212095-160748-8.png" alt="Two screenshots of Cortex XDR warnings. The left screenshot titled &quot;Suspicious theme and sentiment in email&quot; from XDR Analytics, mentions possible malicious email content. The right screenshot titled &quot;Usage of homograph characters detected in an email&quot; also from XDR Analytics, alerts to characters that mimic Latin letters, potentially impersonating a well-known brand or identity." width="1000" height="202" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-212095-160748-8.png 1598w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-212095-160748-8-786x158.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-212095-160748-8-768x155.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-212095-160748-8-1536x310.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-160837" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. Detection of phishing emails that contain suspicious themes and homograph characters.</figcaption></figure>
<p>If you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a> or call:</p>
<ul>
<li>North America: Toll Free: +1 (866) 486-4842 (866.4.UNIT42)</li>
<li>UK: +44.20.3743.3660</li>
<li>Europe and Middle East: +31.20.299.3130</li>

<li>Japan: +81.50.1790.0200</li>
<li>Australia: +61.2.4062.7950</li>
<li>India: 00080005045107</li>
</ul>

CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the <a href="https://www.cyberthreatalliance.org" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cyber Threat Alliance</a>.</p>
<h2><a id="post-160748-_vtt2kpoamyzi"></a>Indicators of Compromise</h2>

</ul>

<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">f05bc36211301087e403df09daa014ea8f04f5bdae5cef75eb866b56b82af2d6</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">c45d3b6d2237fc500688a73d3ba18335d0002917f1a1f09df6934c87deaa097f</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">fcad234dc2ad5e2d8215bcf6caac29aef62666c34564e723fa6d2eee8b6468ed</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">e05b7f44ef8d0b58cfc2f407b84dcff1cb24e0ec392f792a49ad71e7eab39143</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">87c9bede1feac2e3810f3d269b4492fe0902e6303020171e561face400e9bdb4</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">c3de728850dc1e777ad50a211a4be212ca6c4ac9d94bf7bb6d5f7fe5f4574021</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">e5daa86418ac444d590a2c693cd7749d87134c47d8e0dbac30c69f23a8e8131f</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-160748-_c7wk05alyb2p"></a><br />
SHA256 Hashes for Katz Stealer</h3>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">a6b736988246610da83ce17c2c15af189d3a3a4f82233e4fedfabdcbbde0cff0</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">74052cf53b45399b31743a6c4d3a1643e125a277e4ddcfcad4f2903b32bc7dc4</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">20bde6276d6355d33396d5ebfc523b4f4587f706b599573de78246811aabd33c</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">e345d793477abbecc2c455c8c76a925c0dfe99ec4c65b7c353e8a8c8b14da2b6</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">96ada593d54949707437fa39628960b1c5d142a5b1cb371339acc8f86dbc7678</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">925e6375deaa38d978e00a73f9353a9d0df81f023ab85cf9a1dc046e403830a8</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">b249814a74dff9316dc29b670e1d8ed80eb941b507e206ca0dfdc4ff033b1c1f</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">9b6fb4c4dd2c0fa86bffb4c64387e5a1a90adb04cb7b5f7e39352f9eae4b93fa</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">d5ead682c9bed748fd13e3f9d0b7d7bacaf4af38839f2e4a35dc899ef1e261e2</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ece74382ec6f319890e24abbf8e0a022d0a4bd7e0aeaf13c20bab3a37035dcd1</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">2dba8e38ac557374ae8cbf28f5be0541338afba8977fbff9b732dee7cee7b43e</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">11e90765640cbb12b13afa1bcec31f96f50578a5e65e2aa7be24465001b92e41</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">b2245ca7672310681caa52dc72e448983d921463c94cdab0ba9c40ad6b2a58fe</span></li>

<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">309da3c8422422089b7f9af3b1b3f89e2d5c36e48e4d9d9faa07affb7d9a7b17</span></li>

<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">d92bb6e47cb0a0bdbb51403528ccfe643a9329476af53b5a729f04a4d2139647</span></li>

<h2><a id="post-160748-_570cbe1pdhwx"></a>Additional Resources</h2>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.ibm.com/think/x-force/dcrat-presence-growing-in-latin-america" target="_blank" rel="noopener">DCRat Presence Growing in Latin America</a> – IBM</li>
<li><a href="https://malpedia.caad.fkie.fraunhofer.de/details/win.asyncrat" target="_blank" rel="noopener">AsyncRAT Remote Access Tool</a> – Malpedia</li>
<li><a href="https://malpedia.caad.fkie.fraunhofer.de/details/win.xworm" target="_blank" rel="noopener">XWorm Malware</a> – Malpedia</li>
<li><a href="https://malpedia.caad.fkie.fraunhofer.de/details/win.formbook" target="_blank" rel="noopener">FormBook Malware</a> – Malpedia</li>
<li><a href="https://malpedia.caad.fkie.fraunhofer.de/details/win.dcrat" target="_blank" rel="noopener">DCRat Remote Access Tool</a> – Malpedia</li>
<li><a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/msbuild/msbuild?view=vs-2022" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Microsoft Build Engine</a> – Microsoft Learn</li>
<li><a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/003/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Obfuscated Files or Information: Steganography</a> – MITRE</li>
<li><a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1055/012/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Process Injection: Process Hollowing</a> – MITRE</li>
<li><a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1127/001/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Trusted Developer Utilities Proxy Execution: MSBuild</a> – MITRE</li>
<li><a href="https://github.com/robsonfelix/VMDetector" target="_blank" rel="noopener">VMDetector</a> – robsonfelix on GitHub</li>
<li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/homograph-attacks/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">The Ηоmоgraph Illusion: Not Everything Is As It Seems</a> – Unit 42, Palo Alto Networks</li>
</ul>

                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/infostealer/" title="Infostealer" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="phantomvai-loader-delivers-infostealers:related-resources:New Infection Chain and ConfuserEx-Based Obfuscation for DarkCloud Stealer:Infostealer">Infostealer</a>

            </div>
